DT Article
TI About the surprising presence of Donax longissimus Thiele & Jaeckel,
   1931 (Mollusca: Bivalvia: Donacidae) in Western Sahara (Morocco): a
   comparison with similar E Atlantic and South African species.
AU Nolf, Frank (frank.nolf@pandora.be) 
SO Neptunea
VL 13
IS 3
PS 1-26
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Specimens of an unknown Donax have recently been collected off La Sarga,
   Dakhla, Western Sahara, Morocco, a poorly explored area. Similar
   specimens were already known from South Africa. Thorough investigation
   has revealed that these shells belong to Donax longissimus Thiele &
   Jaeckel, 1931,a species often confused with Donax burnupi G.B. Sowerby
   III, 1894 also present in South Africa and Mozambique. In this paper
   Donax longissimus is compared with other similar species from the E
   Atlantic waters and D. prolongatus(Turton, 1932) is regarded as a junior
   synonym.
C1 Nolf, Frank; Pr. Stefanieplein 43/8, B-8400 Oostende, Belgium, Belgium.
EM frank.nolf@pandora.be
SC Zoology
SN 1378-2029
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Synonymy; Marine zones; Atlantic Ocean
DE Donax longissimus [North Atlantic / Morocco / New record; systematics]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Bivalvia, Heterodonta, Veneroida, Tellinoidea
OR Donax burnupi - G.B. Sowerby III 1894 (Tellinoidea): [Syn nov, Donax
   prolongatus (Turton 1932), p. 6]. 
   Donax longissimus - Thiele & Jaeckel 1931 (Tellinoidea): [New record].

DT Article
TI The genus Tomellana (Mollusca: Gastropoda: Clavatulidae) in West Africa:
   a comprehensive survey and establishment of Fusiturris kribiensis
   Bozzetti, 2015 as a junior synonym.
AU Nolf, Frank (frank.nolf@pandora.be) 
SO Neptunea
VL 13
IS 4
PS 17-37
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Tomellana Wenz, 1943 is certainly in need of a detailed
   revision since very limited information is available in recent
   literature. As a consequence of this lack of knowledge a species of
   Tomellana has recently been described as Fusiturris kribiensis Bozzetti,
   2015. It is beyond doubt that the short description and the figures
   represent Tomellana hupferi var. fusca (Strebel, 1912). As a consequence
   the name F. kribiensis has to be considered a junior synonym of
   Tomellana hupferi (Strebel, 1912). On the other hand Tomella pfefferi
   Strebel, 1912 is tentatively regarded as 'Fusiturris' pfefferi (Strebel,
   1912). In the present paper the history of the genus Tomellana is
   presented, the four species are commented upon and with additional
   figures are added.
C1 Nolf, Frank; Pr. Stefanieplein, 43/8, B-8400 Oostende, Belgium, Belgium.
EM frank.nolf@pandora.be
SC Zoology
SN 1378-2029
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position; Marine zones
DE Tomellana [Atlantic Ocean / Africa / Distribution; systematics]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Conoidea
OR Fusiturris? pfefferi - (Strebel 1912) (Conoidea): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Tomella, p. 20]. 
   Tomella pfefferi - (Strebel 1912) (Conoidea): [Referred to, Fusiturris,
   p. 20]. 
   Tomellana - Wenz 1943 (Conoidea). 
   Tomellana hupferi var. fusca - (Strebel 1912) (Conoidea): [Syn nov,

DT Article
TI The Marine Fauna of New Zealand: Sponges in the family Geodiidae
   (Demospongiae: Astrophorina).
AU Sim-Smith, Carina
   Kelly, Michelle
SO NIWA Biodiversity Memoir
VL 128
PS 5-100
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Geodiidae Gray, 1867 of New Zealand (Demospongiae Sollas, 1885:
   Tetractinellida Marshall, 1876: Astrophorina Sollas, 1887) are reviewed
   and inventoried from new and existing collections within the NIWA
   Invertebrate Collection at Wellington, with more than 300 specimens
   examined and registered, four of which are from the Australian Exclusive
   Economic Zone (EEZ). Prior to this work, only four species of Geodiidae
   were described from New Zealand: Erylus niger Bergquist, 1968; Geodia
   rex Dendy, 1924; Geodia regina Dendy, 1924; and Geodia vestigifera
   (Dendy, 1924). We add three new species to the subfamily Erylinae
   Sollas, 1888: E. fallax n. sp., Caminus primus n. sp. and Pachymatisma
   nodosa n. sp., the latter two species being first records of these
   genera in New Zealand waters. In the subfamily Geodiinae Sollas, 1888 we
   add fourteen new species of Geodia to the described fauna (G.
   campbellensis n. sp., G. chathamensis n. sp., G. copiosa n. sp., G. ewok
   n. sp., G. harpago n. sp., G. kermadecensis n. sp., G. leosimi n. sp.,
   G. margarita n. sp., G. praelonga n. sp., G. sadiemillsae n. sp., G.
   sagitta n. sp., G. tenera n. sp., G. vadi n. sp., and G. williami n.
   sp.). Previously described species (E. niger, G. regina, G. rex, G.
   vestigifera and G. vaubani Levi & Levi, 1983), the latter recorded here
   from the vicinity of Norfolk Island in the Australian EEZ, have been
   re-examined and redescribed, including new scanning electron microscope
   (SEM) images. This study brings the total described New Zealand
   Geodiidae fauna to 22 species.
C1 Sim-Smith, Carina; Natl Inst Water & Atmospher Res, Natl Ctr Coasts &
   Oceans, Private Bag 99940, Auckland, 1149, New Zealand, New Zealand.

PT J
AN ZOOR15407037524
DT Article
TI Formidable carpal weaponry of Anas chathamica, Chatham Island's extinct
   flightless duck.
AU Williams, Murray (murraywilliams@paradise.net.nz) 
SO Notornis
VL 62
IS 3
PS 113-120
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Chatham Island duck (Anseriformes: Anatidae: Anas chathamica) had a
   pronounced and rugose enlargement to the tip of the processus
   extensorius at the proximal end of its carpometacarpus. This "carpal
   knob" was the equal in size of those found in some much larger waterfowl
   (e.g., steamer ducks, Tachyeres sp.), and was disproportionately larger
   than those of all other New Zealand waterfowl. The knobs on 20
   carpometacarpi examined all showed evidence of continuous bone
   deposition at their tips and their use as weapons is implied.
   Comparisons with other duck species having similarly prominent and
   rugose carpal knobs suggests the Chatham Island duck maintained
   long-term pair bonds and occupied combined feeding and breeding
   territories year-round which both sexes defended belligerently.
C1 Williams, Murray; 68 Wellington Rd, Paekakariki, 5034, New Zealand, New
   Zealand.
EM murraywilliams@paradise.net.nz
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Behavioral Sciences; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 0029-4470
BD Biometrics; Skeletal and supporting structures; Skeleton; Appendicular
   skeleton; Behaviour; Ecology
DE Anas chathamica [Size / Carpal knob size / comparative study] [Forelimb
   skeleton /  / ] [Social behaviour / Social implications / ] [Ecology /
   Ecological implications / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Anseriformes, Anatidae
OR Anas chathamica (Anatidae).

PT J
AN ZOOR15404019649
DT Article
TI The West Palaearctic Achilidae (Hemiptera, Fulgoromorpha: Fulgoroidea) -
   a review with description of five new species from the Mediterranean.
AU Asche, Manfred (manfred.asche@mfn-berlin.de) 
SO Nova Supplementa Entomologica
VL 25
PS 1-135
PD 2015
PY 2015
NT Dedication to Drosopoulos, A.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Due to their cryptic life and scarcity Achilidae is one of the least
   known and understood families of planthoppers (Fulgoroidea). This work
   represents the first comprehensive review of Achilidae from the West
   Palaearctic. A general update of the current knowledge on morphology,
   taxonomy, systematics, distribution, and ecology of Achilidae is
   presented. With focus on West Palaearctic taxa larval instars of two
   mediterranean species are described and illustrated for the first time.
   For adults, male and female genital structures of all species concerned
   are figured and described. Supplementary descriptions are provided for
   all known species. Biological notes, especially on host plant
   associations wherever available are provided. These have revealed an
   association with Fagaceae (Quercus spp., Fagus spec.) and Pinaceae
   (Pinus spec., Abies spec.); immatures and partly adults feed as
   sap-suckers on hyphae of fungi of Basidiomycota: Polyporales which are
   found on rotten parts under bark of fallen trees. 5 species were
   discovered as new to science: 4 of the genus Cixidia SPINOLA (C.
   anatolica spec. nov. from Turkey, C. maghrebina spec. nov. from Algeria,
   C. malickii spec. nov. from Greece: Crete, C. skaloula spec. nov. from
   Greece), and 1 of the genus Neomenocria FENNAH (N. creticola spec. nov.
   from Greece: Crete), the latter genus here being removed from synonymy
   with Cixidia and newly defined. All West Palaearctic species belong to
   the subfamily Achilinae with a total of 3 genera and 16 species, and are
   assigned to 2 tribes: a single species represents the tribe Plectoderini
   (Akotropis quercicola LINNAVUORI), 15 the tribe Achilini (not counted
   the taxonomically unclear Elidiptera genei SPINOLA where the
   type-specimen is apparently lost). Keys to genera and species of
   Achilini treated in this work are provided. The identity of C. parnassia
   STAL could be clarified by examining the original type revealing the
   misinterpretation of this species by many authors following MELICHAR and
   others in the late 19th and early 20th century. The misinterpreted
   species the largest of West Palaearctic Achilidae is here described as
   new (C. skaloula spec. nov.). 13 species belong to Cixidia and are
   members of the subtribe Cixidiina; 2 species belong to Neomenocria and
   are tentatively assigned to the subtribe Elidipterina. With a slight
   modification of hitherto used subgeneric criteria sensu ANUFRIEV all
   West Palaearctic Cixidia species can be assigned to the subgenus
   Epiptera METCALF, with the exception of the genotype Cixidia confinis
   (ZETTERSTEDT). Despite of the scarcity and fragmentary documentation of
   West Palaearctic Achilidae, geographic hot spots for species richness
   appear to be in Greece (7 species), Turkey (5 species), and Italy (4
   species). The necessity of future faunistic, ecological, morphological,
   and taxonomic work is emphasized.
C1 Asche, Manfred; Humboldt Univ, Leibniz Inst Res Evolut & Biodivers,
   Invalidenstr 43, Berlin, D-10115, Germany, Germany.
EM manfred.asche@mfn-berlin.de
SC History &Philosophy of Science; Zoology
SN 0948-6038
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type material; Description;
   Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Key; Animals and
   man; Documentation; Publications; General morphology; Life cycle and
   development; Associations; Parasites diseases and disorders; Hosts;
   Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Africa; Eurasia; Asia; Europe;
   Greece

PT J
AN ZOOR15503012854
DT Article
TI Pied Flycatchers Ficedula hypoleuca prefer ectoparasite-free nest sites
   when old nest material is present.
AU Breistol, Arild (arild.breistol@uib.no) 
   Hogstedt, Goran
   Lislevand, Terje
SO Ornis Norvegica
VL 38
PS 9-13
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Nest-dwelling ectoparasitic arthropods may have detrimental effects on
   avian breeding success and fitness. Birds should therefore be selected
   to avoid nest sites where the risk of being infested by ectoparasites is
   high. However, studies testing this hypothesis have produced mixed
   results. We performed an experiment in south Norway to test whether Pied
   Flycatchers Ficedula hypoleuca select nest site according to the
   presence of ectoparasites. In this experiment we used artificial nest
   boxes which had all been successfully used by conspecifics in the
   previous breeding season and still contained the old nest material. Five
   different groups of ectoparasites were recorded in flycatcher nests in
   the study area, of which the haematophagous hen flea Ceratophyllus
   gallinae and mites (Dermanyssus sp.) occurred in all examined nests. We
   offered each flycatcher pair (n = 13) a choice between 1) a box where
   ectoparasites had been removed by insecticide fumigation and 2) a box in
   which the old nest had not been fumigated. Flycatchers were highly
   selective in their choice of nest site, all but one settling in the
   fumigated, parasite-free nest box. This finding differs from a similar
   Swedish study (Olsson & Allander 1995) which did not find any evidence
   that Pied Flycatchers avoided nest boxes with ectoparasites. A likely
   explanation for this discrepancy is between-population differences in
   parasite abundance, as the mean number of hen fleas per infested nest
   was about five times higher in Norway than in Sweden.
C1 Breistol, Arild; Univ Bergen, Dept Biol, Box 7803, Bergen, N-5020,
   Norway, Norway.
EM arild.breistol@uib.no
OI Lislevand, Terje/0000-0003-1281-7061
SC Parasitology; Zoology; Forestry; Reproductive Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 1502-0878
BD Reproduction; Reproductive behaviour; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts; Ecology; Habitat utilization; Animal
   constructions; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Ceratophyllus gallinae; Dermanyssus; Hippoboscidae; Mallophaga;
   Trypocalliphora braueri [Avian hosts / Ficedula hypoleuca / Prevalence]
   [Forest and woodland / Forest / ] [Norway / Aust-Agder county, Hornnes /
   ]. 
   Ficedula hypoleuca [Breeding site / Breeding site preference /
   prevalence] [Arachnid parasites / Dermanyssus / ] [Dipteran parasites /
   Trypocalliphora braueri / ] [ / Hippoboscidae / ] [Mallophagan parasites
   /  / ] [Siphonapteran parasites / Ceratophyllus gallinae / ] [Habitat
   preference /  / ] [Nests / Old nest materials / ] [Forest and woodland /
   Forest / ] [Norway / Aust-Agder county, Hornnes / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Birds; Chelicerates; Chordates; Insects;
   Invertebrates; True Flies; Vertebrates

   Cyclorrhapha, Calliphoridae, Siphonaptera, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves,
   Passeriformes, Muscicapidae

DT Article
TI On some 'lost' types of Cerambyx and Leptura species described by
   Linnaeus (1758), and a new synonymy in Rhinotragini (Coleoptera,
   Cerambycidae).
AU Santos-Silva, Antonio (toncriss@uol.com.br) 
SO Papeis Avulsos de Zoologia (Sao Paulo)
VL 55
IS 29
PS 397-403
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The depository institution of the types of five species described by
   Linnaeus (1758), which is currently recorded as "unknown", is reported
   to be at the Naturhistoriska Riksmuseet, Stockholm, Sweden: Cerambyx
   auratus; C. festivus; C. glaucus; C. stigma; and Leptura necydalea. The
   synonymy between Acyphoderes odyneroides White, 1855 (currently,
   Acutiphoderes odyneroides) and Leptura necydalea Linnaeus, 1758 is
   proposed, resulting in a new combination: Acutiphoderes necydalea.
C1 Santos-Silva, Antonio; Univ Sao Paulo, Museu Zool, Caixa Postal 42-494,
   Sao Paulo, SP, BR-04218970 BC, Brazil, Brazil.
EM toncriss@uol.com.br
SC Education &Educational Research; Zoology
SN 0031-1049; 1807-0205

   Animals and man; Education and entertainment; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe
DE Cerambycidae [Museums collections and exhibitions / Swedish State
   Natural History Museum / Systematics; specimens described by Linnaeus]
   [Sweden / Stockholm / ].

PT J
AN ZOOR15311067233
DT Article
TI [Two new species of earthworms (Oligochaeta: Tumakidae) in the Caribbean
   region of Colombia.]
FT Dos especies nuevass (Oligochaeta: Tumakidae) de la region Caribe de
   Colombia.
AU Celis, Liliana V. (Ivcelisg@unal.edu.co) 
   Rangel-Ch, Orlando
SO Papeis Avulsos de Zoologia (Sao Paulo)
VL 55
IS 30
PS 405-414
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new species of earthworms (Oligochaeta: Annelida) Tumakidae family;
   Tumak amari sp. nov. and Tumak congorum sp. nov. are described and
   illustrated. They were collected in relict forest fragments adjacent to
   wetlands in the southerm region of Cesar department of Cesar, in the
   Colombian Caribbean. Tumakidae family is characterized mainly by of the
   calciferous gland before the gizzard and the presence of dorsal pores.
   Tumak amari sp. nov. and Tumak congorum sp. nov. are close to Tumak
   hammeni (Righi, 1995), but they differ by the clitelum extension, the
   puberal zone, the testicular sacs, the position of the male pores, and
   by the number, shape and position of spermathecae. The new species are
   the first records of the genus after the original description.
C1 Celis, Liliana V.; Univ Nacl Colombia, Inst Ciencias Nat, AA 14490,
   Bogota Dc, Colombia, Colombia.
EM Ivcelisg@unal.edu.co
SC Zoology
SN 0031-1049; 1807-0205
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Neotropical
   region; South America
DE Tumak amari; Tumak congorum [Colombia /  / New species]. 
   Tumakidae [Colombia /  / Distribution; new record; systematics]. 
TN Annelids; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Annelida, Oligochaeta
OR Tumak - Righi 1996 (Oligochaeta): [Diagnostic characters of subordinate
   taxa, P. 412]. 
   Tumak amari (Oligochaeta): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 407]. 
   Tumak congorum (Oligochaeta): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 410]. 
   Tumakidae - Righi 1996 (Oligochaeta): [Diagnostic characters of
   subordinate taxa, P. 412; Emended diagnosis, P. 407; New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR15301005975
DT Article
TI Dipteran leafminers and an associated parasitoid in canola in
   Saskatchewan.
AU Andreassen, L.D.
   Wist, T.J. (Tyler.Wist@canada.ca) 
   Soroka, J.J.
SO Proceedings of the Entomological Society of Manitoba
VL 71
PS 20-26
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Many species of insect herbivores feed on canola on the Canadian
   Prairies, but none have been reported to mine canola leaves. Mines were
   noted in canola leaves near Melfort, Saskatchewan in 2014, and near
   Prince Albert, Saskatchewan in 2015. Fly larvae were dissected from the
   mines and reared. Two adult Scaptomyza flava (Fallen) (Diptera:
   Drosophilidae), one adult Liriomyza sp. (Diptera: Drosophilidae) and two
   adult parasitoids Halticoptera patellana (Dalman) (Hymenoptera:
   Pteromalidae) emerged. The mines and lifecycles of the two species of
   flies are described. Based on experiences in other parts of the world,
   neither species is expected to become a significant pest of canola on
   the Prairies.
C1 Wist, T.J.; Agr & Agri Food Canada, Saskatoon Res Stn, 107 Sci Pl,
   Saskatoon, SK, S7N 0X2, Canada, Canada.
EM Tyler.Wist@canada.ca
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0315-2146
BD Parasites diseases and disorders; Parasites; Insect parasites; Hosts;
   Insect hosts; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America; Canada
DE Halticoptera patellana [Dipteran hosts / Liriomyza / ] [ / Scaptomyza
   flava / Recorded] [Saskatchewan /  / ]. 
   Liriomyza; Scaptomyza flava [Hymenopteran parasites / Halticoptera
   patellana / Recorded; plant host] [Plant hosts / Brassica napus / New
   record; associated hymenopteran parasite] [Saskatchewan /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Brachycera, Cyclorrhapha,
   Agromyzidae, Drosophilidae, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Terebrantia,
   Chalcidoidea, Pteromalidae
OR Liriomyza (Agromyzidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Scaptomyza flava (Drosophilidae): [Host; New record]. 
   Halticoptera patellana (Pteromalidae): [Parasite]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15301005975
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR15302011732
DT Article
TI Intertidal records of 'sea slugs' (nudibranchs and allied opisthobranch
   gastropods) from northern North Island, New Zealand.
AU Morley, Margaret S.
   Hayward, Bruce W. (b.hayward@geomarine.org.nz) 
SO Records of the Auckland Museum
VL 50
PS 33-75
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We record the intertidal or shallow subtidal (< 2-3 m) occurrence of 78
   species of 'sea slug' from northern North Island of New Zealand. One
   (Goniodoris n.sp.) is recorded for the first time. The majority are
   briefly described, illustrated and their records plotted on maps. Three
   taxa are probably undescribed new species. All except two (Aphelodoris
   sp., Trinchesia reflexa) of the species have been recorded from along
   the east coast (warmer water Aupourian Province) but only 44% (34 spp.)
   have been recorded from the west coast (cooler Cookian Province). The
   highest diversity of intertidal/shallow water 'sea slugs' has been
   recorded from the Leigh area (47 spp.), Bay of Islands (42 spp.) and
   Great Barrier Island (38 spp.) reflecting the intensity of survey
   (Leigh) and diversity of habitats on the warmer coast (latter two). Of
   the harbours, 33 spp. are recorded from the Waitemata, 27 spp. from
   Parengarenga and 24 spp. from the Manukau, reflecting the intensity of
   survey (Waitemata, Manukau) and unusual warm conditions of far north
   Parengarenga. Of the 'sea slugs' recorded herein, 45% are endemic to New
   Zealand and nine of these are endemic to northern New Zealand.
C1 Hayward, Bruce W.; Geomarine Res, 19 Debron Ave, Remuera, New Zealand,
   New Zealand.
EM b.hayward@geomarine.org.nz
SC Environmental Sciences &Ecology; Zoology; Marine &Freshwater Biology
SN 1174-9202
BD Ecology; Community structure; Habitat; Marine habitat; Zoogeography;
   Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Nudibranchia; Opisthobranchia [Species diversity /  / systematics]
   [Population dynamics / Seasonal abundance / ] [Marine shore habitat /
   Intertidal & subtidal habitat / distribution] [Zoogeography /
   Biogeography / ] [South Pacific / New Zealand, north / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Opisthobranchia
OR Opisthobranchia (Gastropoda). 
   Nudibranchia (Opisthobranchia). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15302011732
DA 2020-09-17

AN ZOOR15508054365

TI A NEW CHILEAN SPECIES OF THE GENUS PROEULIA CLARKE AND ADDITIONAL
   DISTRIBUTIONAL RECORDS FOR FIVE SPECIES (LEPIDOPTERA: TORTRICIDAE).
FT NUEVA ESPECIE DEL GENERO PROEULIA CLARKE, CON REGISTROS ADICIONALES DE
   DISTRIBUCION GEOGRAFICA PARA CINCO ESPECIES (LEPIDOPTERA: TORTRICIDAE).
AU Cepeda, Danilo E. (museoent@uchile.cl) 
   Gonzalez, Roberto H.
SO Revista Chilena de Entomologia
VL 40
PS 1-8
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of the genus Proeulia, P. filigranae nov. sp. is described
   for Chile. The taxonomic description was based in field specimens
   collected on its host plant, Lobelia excelsa. The material obtained was
   reared under laboratory conditions. In addition, the new records of
   other Proeulia species are provided.
C1 Cepeda, Danilo E.; Univ Chile, Fac Ciencias Agron, Santiago, Chile,
   Chile.

AN ZOOR15502010101
DT Article
TI MAWIDA, NEW GENUS OF OECOPHORIDAE (LEPIDOPTERA: GELECHIOIDEA) OF CENTRAL
   CHILE.
FT MAWIDA, NUEVO GENERO DE OECOPHORIDAE (LEPIDOPTERA: GELECHIOIDEA) DE
   CHILE CENTRAL.
AU Urra Lagos, Francisco (francisco.urra@mnhn.cl) 
SO Revista Chilena de Entomologia
VL 40
PS 22-29
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new monospecific genus of Oecophoridae, Mawida nov. gen., is described
   based on specimens collected in central Chile. Diagnostic characters for
   the genus and species are given, photographs of adult and illustrations
   of wing venation and structures of the genitalia are provided. Also, its
   host plant is reported.

   Chile, Chile.

PT J
AN ZOOR15303014813
DT Article
TI RISK FACTORS ASSOCIATED TO THE SEROPREVALENCE OF TOXOPLASMA GONDII IN
   CAPTIVE MAMMALS FROM CARNIVORA AND PRIMATE ORDER.
FT Factores de Riesgo Asociados a la Seroprevalencia de Toxoplasma gondii
   en Mamiferos del Orden Carnivora y Primates Mantenidos en Cautiverio.
AU Navarro M, Dennis
   Chavez, Amanda, V (achavezvg@gmail.com) 
   Pinedo, Rosa, V
   Munoz D, Karina
SO Revista de Investigaciones Veterinarias del Peru
VL 26
IS 3
PS 497-508
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Spanish
U1 0
U2 0
AB The objective of this study was to determine the seroprevalence of T.
   gondii in captive wild animals of the Carnivora and Primates orders and
   identify the epidemiologic variables involved in its presentation. The
   study was conducted at the Patronato del Parque de las Leyendas Zoo,
   Lima, Peru. Blood samples were collected (Carnivora, n=49; Primates,
   n=52). In addition, samples were collected from 87 urban rodents and 18
   domestic cats captured in the zoo. Surveys were done to identify
   potencial risk factors for each Order. Furthermore, morphometric
   parameters, estimated age, sex and body weight from rats and age and sex
   from cats were recorded. Indirect hemaglutination test was used for the
   diagnosis of T. gondii. Dilutions were prepared from 1: 16 to 1: 2048,
   considering positive a titre over 1/16. IgM antibodies were measured by
   using 2-Mercaptoethanol to determinate acute infections. The
   associations between the seroprevalence to T. gondii and the variables
   sex, origin, time in the institution and type of feeding were analyzed
   by the odds ratio (OR). The seroprevalence of T. gondii in captive
   mammals of the Carnivora and Primates orders was 87.8 and 80.8%
   respectively. Significant association (p<0.05) was only found between
   seroprevalence of T. gondii in Primates and the type of feeds, where the
   omnivore diet had a significant risk factor (OR: 40.9) for the
   presentation of the infection. The frequency of anti-T. gondii
   antibodies in rodents (Rattus sp) and cats was 25.3 and 77.8%
   respectively.
C1 Chavez, Amanda, V; Univ Nacl Mayor San Marcos, Fac Med Vet, Lima, Peru,
   Peru.
EM achavezvg@gmail.com
OI NAVARRO, DENNIS/0000-0002-5129-6599; PINEDO VICENTE, ROSA
   YSABEL/0000-0001-5093-132X
SC Anatomy &Morphology; Zoology; Nutrition &Dietetics; Reproductive
   Biology; Parasitology; Immunology
SN 1682-3419; 1609-9117
BD Biometrics; Nutrition; Reproduction; Parasites diseases and disorders;
   Parasites; Hosts; Immunology and repair mechanisms; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Carnivora; Primates [Biometrics / Morphometrics / prevalence; in
   captivity] [Age /  / ] [Weight / Body weight / ] [Diet /  / ] [Sex
   differences /  / ] [Protozoan parasites / Toxoplasma gondii / ] [Peru /
   Lima, Patronato del Parque de las Leyendas Zoo / ]. 
   Felidae; Rodentia [Age /  / prevalence] [Weight / Body weight / ] [Sex
   differences /  / ] [Protozoan parasites / Toxoplasma gondii / ] [Immune
   response / Antibodies / ]. 
   Toxoplasma gondii [Mammalian hosts / Carnivora / Prevalence; captive
   hosts] [ / Felidae / ] [ / Primates / ] [ / Rodentia / ] [Peru / Lima,
   Patronato del Parque de las Leyendas Zoo / ].

DT Article
TI The small mammals of Ceara (marsupials, bats and sigmodontine rodents)
   with a taxonomic discussion of some species.
FT Pequenos mamiferos do Ceara (marsupiais, morcegos e roedores
   sigmodontineos) com discussao taxonomica de algumas especies.
AU Gurgel-Filho, Newton M. (bionewton@gmail.com) 
   Feijo, Anderson
   Langguth, Alfredo
SO Revista Nordestina de Biologia
VL 23
IS 2
PS 3-150
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 0
AB We examined 1.344 specimens of small mammals collected in the state of
   Ceara corresponding to 63 species of which 9 were marsupials, 49 were
   Chiroptera and13 were sigmodontine rodents distributed in 50 genera and
   10 families, from 41 regions and municipalities. The material studied
   belongs to Brazilian mammal collections. The material identifed so far
   as Calomys expulsus from Brazilian Northeast belongs to a new species
   described here. According to the original description of Linnaeus
   Didelphis marsupialis is a white-eared opossum and the black-eared
   opossum should be called Didelphis karkinophaga. The name Bolomys
   Thomas, 1916 is used here because its type species is much more
   informative than the fragmentary fossil remains that define Necromys
   Ameghino, 1889. Range extension of several species were recorded mainly
   in Brejo Altitudinal forest.
C1 Gurgel-Filho, Newton M.; Univ Fed Paraiba, CCEN, Joao Pessoa, Paraiba,
   BR-58059900 BC, Brazil, Brazil.

DT Article
TI The terrestrial snail family Streptaxidae J.Gray, 1860 (Gastropoda:
   Pulmonata) from Son La, Vietnam, with description of two new species.
AU Do Duc Sang (doducsangdhtb@gmail.com) 
   Do Van Nhuong
SO Ruthenica
VL 25
IS 2
PS 37-43
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The family Streptaxidae comprises 8 species and subspecies occurring in
   Son La, north-western Vietnam. The present paper provides data relevant
   to these species and the descriptions of two new species. Stemmatopsis
   nangphaiensis sp. nov. has an oblique- heliciform shell with elevated
   spire. The aperture is quadrangular with rounded angles, toothless,
   peristome is thick and slightly expanded. Stemmatopsis vanhoensis sp.
   nov. has a depressed-heliciform shell. The umbilicus is wide with long
   curvy furrow. The aperture is quadrangular and toothless, peristome is
   very thick and expanded.
C1 Do Duc Sang; Tay Bac Univ, Dept Zool, Son La, Vietnam, Vietnam.

AN ZOOR15307041107
DT Article
TI Forgotten species from the Bering Strait - Buccinum rodgersi Gould, 1860
   (Neogastropoda: Buccinidae).
AU Merkuljev, A.V. (amerkuljev@gmail.com) 
SO Ruthenica
VL 25
IS 3
PS 89-92
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB Buccinum rodgersi Gould, 1860, described from the Bering strait (between
   the Bering and Chukchi Seas) was never recorded or mentioned in
   literature since 1883 (with the exception of bibliographical work by R.
   Johnson, 1964). Although the species name was not used in current
   literature, the species was recorded in the Far-East seas of Russia
   (Sirenko, 2009; Sirenko et al., 2013) under other name, Plicifusus
   mcleani Sirenko, 2009. In this paper Buccinum rodgersi is transferred to
   Plicifusus Dall, 1902. Plicifusus mcleani is considered its junior
   synonym.
C1 Merkuljev, A.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Nab 1, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM amerkuljev@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0136-0027

   position

ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Neogastropoda, Muricoidea
OR Buccinum rodgersi - Gould 1860 (Muricoidea): [Referred to, Plicifusus,
   p. 90]. 
   Plicifusus rodgersi - (Gould 1860) (Muricoidea): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Buccinum, p. 90; Syn nov, Plicifusus mcleanii Sirenko 2009, p. 90].

DT Article
TI The Bering Sea prosobranchiate gastropod species described by A. Krause
   in 1885.
AU Merkuljev, A.V. (amerkuljev@gmail.com) 
SO Ruthenica
VL 25
IS 4
PS 133-137
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Russian
U1 0
U2 0
AB In 1881 expedition of the Bremen Geographical Society collected molluscs
   in the north-western part of the Bering Sea off the coast of Chukotka.
   The result of this work has not been fully appreciated by Russian
   malacologists since it was believed that the German expedition was
   working in American, not Asian waters. In this paper on the basis of
   materials from the collection of the Berlin Museum of Natural History as
   well as published data, it is proved that molluscs were collected off
   Asian coast. Photos of the types of Gastropoda described A. Krause, are
   presented for the first time. "Bela" luetkeana Krause, 1885
   (Mangeliidae) is attributed herein to the genus Propebela Iredale, 1918.
C1 Merkuljev, A.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Nab 1, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM amerkuljev@gmail.com

TI Leptochiton antarcticus (Mollusca, Polyplacophora) - a new species from
   the Southern Ocean.
AU Sirenko, B.I. (marine@zin.ru) 
SO Ruthenica
VL 25
IS 4
PS 139-146
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of chiton, Leptochiton antarcticus n. sp., is described
   from the Southern Ocean from depths of 87-1,524 m. The new species is
   distinguishable from other congeneric species by the shape of head, of
   major lateral teeth of radula, dorsal scales and anterior position of
   mucro.

TI BAFICRINUS GEN. NOV (CRINOIDEA, INADUNATA) FROM THE BOHEMIAN EARLY
   DEVONIAN (THE CZECH REPUBLIC).

   Nohejlova, Martina
SO Sbornik Narodniho Muzea v Praze Rada B Prirodni Vedy
VL 71
IS 1-2
PS 25-30
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In washings of weathered Trebotov Limestone of Early Devonian, Late
   Emsian age, isolated radials and rarely, the almost complete calyxes of
   new zophocrinid crinoids, have been found. These crinoids are closely
   related to the genus Tiaracrinus and are described here as a new genus
   and new species, Baficrinus vigilis gen. nov. et sp. nov. A list of
   crinoid taxa and parataxa described from the Trebotov Limestone in the
   Barrandian Area is included herein.

DT Article
TI SABELLID AND SERPULID WORMS (POLYCHAETA, CANALIPALPATA, SABELLIDA,
   SABELLIDAE, SERPULIDAE) FROM THE ROCKY COAST FACIES (LATE CENOMANIAN) AT
   PREDBOJ NEAR PRAGUE.
AU Koci, Tomas (protula@seznam.cz) 
   Jaeger, Manfred
SO Sbornik Narodniho Muzea v Praze Rada B Prirodni Vedy
VL 71
IS 1-2
PS 31-50
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The relatively rich assemblage of tube dwelling polychaetes including
   sabellid (Sabellidae) and serpulid (Serpulidae) worms (Polychaeta,
   Canalipalpata) from the classical rocky coast facies locality Predboj
   (Late Cenomanian - Early Turonian, Vltava-Beroun area, Bohemian
   Cretaceous Basin) is described in detail for the first time in a single
   publication. Ten genera: Glomerula, Filogranula, Neovermilia, Cementula,
   Laqueoserpula, Dorsoserpula, Placostegus, Pyrgopolon, Neomicrorbis, and
   Bipygmaeus are represented by 16 species, some of them are described in
   open nomenclature. Two of the species are new: Pyrgopolon (Septenaria)
   nekvasilovae sp. nov. and Pyrgopolon (Septenaria) zitti sp. nov. All
   species are described, and their systematics, taxonomy and palaeoecology
   are discussed.
C1 Koci, Tomas; Natl Museum, Nat Hist Museum, Vaclavske Namesti 68, Prague,
   CZ-11579, Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM protula@seznam.cz

DT Article
TI PAUXILLITES THADDEI A NEW LOWER ORDOVICIAN HYOLITH FROM MOROCCO.
AU Valent, Martin (martin_valent@nm.cz) 
   Corbacho, Joan
SO Sbornik Narodniho Muzea v Praze Rada B Prirodni Vedy
VL 71
IS 1-2
PS 51-54
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new rare hyolith species Pauxillites thaddei sp. nov. is described
   from the Lower Ordovician (Floian) Fezouata Formation of Morocco. This
   new species differs from all other species of the genus Pauxillites
   MAREK, 1966 by its longer narrow clavicles, which extend to 4/5 of the
   diameter of the operculum. The newly described species adds to the high
   diversity of Ordovician hyoliths in the West Gondwana realm.

U1 0
U2 0
AB The enigmatic Cretaceous coral genus Glenarea is revised on the basis of
   the type specimen of its type species Glenarea cretacea POCTA, 1887. The
   provenance of the large silicified specimen is discussed. Glenarea has
   an unusual morphology and resembles the Eocene coral genera
   Triphyllocoenia and Ewaldocoenia. Both the latter genera are revised
   here as well, resulting in synonymisation of Ewaldocoenia with
   Triphyllocoenia. Glenarea shows fewer than 10 thick, unconnected septa
   that lack any symmetry in their arrangement. Skeletal elements such as
   columella, pali and endotheca are absent. The genus is only known from
   the type specimen. For the coral material that was assigned to Glenarea
   after 1991, the genus Sakalavastraea ALLOITEAU, 1958 with the type
   species S. collignoni from the Callovian of Madagascar is applied.
   Another three species are assigned to the genus, one of which is new.
   The range of Sakalavastraea is considerably extended from Callovian to
   Cenomanian; the genus is distributed worldwide.
C1 Loser, Hannes; Univ Nacl Autonoma Mexico, Estn Reg Noroeste, Blvd Luis
   Donaldo Col Los Arcos, Hermosillo, Sonora, 83250, Mexico, Mexico.
EM hloeser@gmx.net
SC Zoology
SN 0036-5343
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Glenarea [Czech Republic / Bohemia / taxonomic revision] [Cretaceous / 
   / ]. 
   Sakalavastraea [Cretaceous / Cenomanian / New record]. 
   Sakalavastraea perturbata [Czech Republic /  / new species] [Cretaceous
   /  / ].

   Discussion, p. 365]. 
   Sakalavastraea (Scleractinia): [Fossil].

DT Article
TI Devonian tabulate corals from pebbles in Mesozoic conglomerate, Kotaki,
   Niigata Prefecture, central Japan Part 2: Alveolitina.
AU Niko, Shuji
   Ibaraki, Yousuke
   Tazawa, Jun-ichi
SO Science Reports of Niigata University Geology
VL 30
PS 15-25
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB As the second fascicle, this paper describes five species of Devonian
   alveolitine tabulate corals from limestone pebbles in Mesozoic
   conglomerate of the Kotaki area, Niigata Prefecture, central Japan. They
   are Alveolites sp. indet., Crassialveolites niigataensis Niko, Ibaraki
   and Tazawa sp. nov., Squameoalveolites sp. indet., Coenites? sp. indet.,
   Planocoenites sp. indet., and Roseoporella? sp. indet. A Middle Devonian
   species, Crassialveolites tumefactus Tchi, 1980, from North China is
   most similar to this new species, but they can separate in growth forms
   of the coralla and presence or absence of the septal spines. Until now,
   occurrences of Crassialveolites and Squameoalveolites have not been
   known in Japan.
C1 Niko, Shuji; Hiroshima Univ, Dept Environm Studies, Higashihiroshima,
   Hiroshima, 7398521, Japan, Japan.
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1349-1237
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic

   Niigata Prefecture, Kotaki area / ] [Devonian /  / ]. 
   Crassialveolites; Squameoalveolites [Japan /  / new record] [Devonian / 
   / ]. 
   Crassialveolites niigataensis [Japan /  / new species] [Devonian /  / ].
   
TN Coelenterates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Cnidaria, Anthozoa, Zoantharia, Tabulata
OR Alveolitina (Tabulata): [Fossil]. 
   Crassialveolites (Tabulata): [Fossil; New record].

   Squameoalveolites (Tabulata): [Fossil; New record].

DT Article
TI Early Permian (Sakmarian) brachiopods from the Nagaiwa-Sakamotozawa
   area, South Kitakami Belt, northeastern Japan, Part 3: Productidina.
AU Tazawa, Jun-ichi
   Shintani, Tomohiko
SO Science Reports of Niigata University Geology
VL 30
PS 39-55
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In this third manuscript in a series, the following 10 species of
   productid brachiopods (suborder Productidina), including one new
   species, are described from the lowest part of the Sakamotozawa
   Formation (Sakmarian) in the Nagaiwa-Sakamotozawa area, South Kitakami
   Belt, northeastern Japan: Echinauris opuntia (Waagen), Reticulatia cf.
   donetziana (Licharew), Echinaria sp., Juresania sp., Waagenoconcha
   hurnboldti (d' Orbigny), Edriosteges cf. multispinosus Muir-Wood and
   Cooper, Linoproductus simensis (Tschernyschew), Auriculispina kanmerai
   Tazawa and Shintani, sp. nov., Terrakea sp. and Cyclacantharia sp. The
   Nagaiwa-Sakamotozawa fauna is a mixed Boreal-Tethyan fauna, with a
   predominance of Boreal elements.

   Japan.

   Kitakami Belt, Nagaiwa-Sakamotozawa area / ] [Permian / Early Permian /

DT Article
TI Microphallus magnagulletum n. sp (Digenea: Microphallidae) from Black
   Coot, Fulica atra (Gruiformes: Rallidae) in Sindh province of Pakistan.
AU Birmani, N.A. (birmani@gmail.com) 
   Dharejo, A.M.
   Khan, M.M.
   Shaikh, A.M.
   Shah, M.A.
SO Sindh University Research Journal - Science Series
VL 47
IS 3
PS 451-454
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB In result of ongoing research work on the helminth parasites of Fulica
   atra (Gruiformes: Rallidae) in Sind province of Pakistan, a total of 07
   flukes of the genus Microphallus Ward, 1901 were recovered from the
   intestine. On the basis of characteristics like body shape and size,
   very expansive or broad esophagus, small irregularly lobed thick-walled
   intestineal ceca, shape and location of male and female genital organs
   like testes and ovary, measurement of oral sucker and ventral sucker and
   seminal vesicle V-shaped, a new species Microphallus magnagulletum is
   recommended. The new species name indicate to broader esophagus.
C1 Birmani, N.A.; Univ Sindh, Dept Zool, Jamshoro, Sindh, Pakistan,
   Pakistan.
EM birmani@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 1813-1743

   Parasites; Helminth parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Fulica atra [Digenean parasites / Microphallus magnagulletum / New
   parasite species] [Pakistan /  / New platyhelminth parasite species]. 
   Microphallus magnagulletum [Avian hosts / Fulica atra / New parasite
   species] [Pakistan /  / New species from avian host]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Invertebrates; Platyhelminths; Vertebrates

DT Article
TI Taxonomy of Deep-Sea Trachyleberidid, Thaerocytherid, and Hemicytherid
   Genera (Ostracoda).
AU Yasuhara, Moriaki (moriakiyasuhara@gmail.com) 
   Hunt, Gene
   Okahashi, Hisayo
   Brandao, Simone N.
SO Smithsonian Contributions to Paleobiology
VL 96
PS i-xi, 1-213
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB We conducted a comprehens-ive systematic revision of deep-sea
   Trachyleberididae, Thaerocytheridae, and Hemicytheridae (Ostracoda,
   Crustacea) covering almost all Cenozoic genera using high-resolution
   scanning electron microscopy. Trachyleberididae, our main focus, is one
   of the most diverse and abundant ostracod families, but its genus-level
   taxonomy is still confusing. Approximately 700 specimens from 177
   species from 47 genera were examined. The studied samples range in age
   from the Cretaceous to the present day and cover all major oceans in the
   world, including the Atlantic, Pacific, Indian, and Southern Oceans, the
   Mediterranean Sea, and the Gulf of Mexico. Five new genera and 45 new
   species are described: Bensonodutoitella gen. nov., Hornibrookoleberis
   gen. nov., Croninocythereis gen. nov., Bensonocosta gen. nov.,
   Ryugucivis gen. nov., Abyssocythere scotti sp. nov., Ambocythere
   tomocaudata sp. nov., Ambocythere whatleyi sp. nov., Ambocythere
   hyakunome sp. nov., Atlanticythere bensoni sp. nov., Atlanticythere
   oculi sp. nov., Dutoitella cronini sp. nov., Dutoitella symmetrica sp.
   nov., Dutoitella mazziniae sp. nov., Dutoitella paradinglei sp. nov.,
   Dutoitella ayressi sp. nov., Dutoitella colesi sp. nov., Dutoitella
   spinosa sp. nov., Dutoitella whatleyi sp. nov., Dutoitella atlantiformis
   sp. nov., Bensonodutoitella bicornigeri sp. nov., Oligocythereis
   sylvesterbradleyi sp. nov., Cythereis guerneti sp. nov., Cythereis
   johnnealei sp. nov., Cythereis parajohnnealei sp. nov., Cythereis
   neoanteplana sp. nov., Cythereis sylvesterbradleyi sp. nov., Cythereis
   bensoni sp. nov., Cythereis purii sp. nov., Cythereis fungina sp. nov.,
   Cythereis tomcronini sp. nov., Cythereis legitimoformis sp. nov.,
   Cythereis richardbensoni sp. nov., Cythereis dinglei sp. nov., Cythereis
   ovi sp. nov., Cythereis swansoni sp. nov., Croninocythereis tridentiferi
   sp. nov., Croninocythereis cronini sp. nov., Bensonocosta bensoni sp.
   nov., Ayressoleberis colesi sp. nov., Leguminocythereis? buzasi sp.
   nov., Legitimocythere tomi sp. nov., Ryugucivis jablonskii sp. nov.,
   Ryugucivis acuminata sp. nov., Ryugucivis obtusa sp. nov.,
   Phacorhabdotus mazzinireticulatus sp. nov., Phacorhabdotus nudus sp.
   nov., Phacorhabdotus slipperi sp. nov., Taracythere ayressoabyssora sp.
   nov., and Taracythere thalassoformis sp. nov. Emended concepts are
   proposed for several important genera to better stabilize their
   taxonomy. This study considerably reduces taxonomic uncertainty of this
   important component of the modern and fossil deep-sea ostracod community
   and provides a robust taxonomic baseline for deep-sea ostracod-based
   paleoceanographic, paleoecological, and macroevolutionary research.
C1 Yasuhara, Moriaki; Univ Hong Kong, Sch Biol Sci, Pokfulam Rd, Hong Kong,
   Hong Kong, China, China.
EM moriakiyasuhara@gmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0081-0266

   Description; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Documentation; Publications; Evolution; Ecology; Marine zones; Atlantic
   Ocean; North Atlantic; Indian Ocean; Pacific Ocean; Geological time
   periods; Caenozoic; Quaternary; Tertiary; Neogene; Palaeogene; Mesozoic

PT J
AN ZOOR15301003094
DT Article
TI Types of Ampullariidae (Mollusca: Gastropoda) in the National Museum of
   Natural History, Smithsonian Institution, with Lectotype Designations.
AU Cowie, Robert H.
   Hayes, Kenneth A. (kenneth.hayes@howard.edu) 
   Strong, Ellen E.
SO Smithsonian Contributions to Zoology
VL 645
PS i-iv, 1-13
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The caenogastropod family Ampullariidae Gray, 1824, is a family of
   freshwater snails predominantly distributed in humid tropical and
   subtropical habitats in Africa, South and Central America, and Asia. The
   family includes the largest of all freshwater snails and frequently
   constitutes a major portion of the native freshwater malacofauna of
   these regions. Ampullariid taxonomy is confused primarily because most
   species were described on the basis of only shell morphology, which is
   highly variable within species yet relatively conservative among species
   within the family. The need for rigorous taxonomic treatment of the
   group is acute, and a starting point for such research is a
   comprehensive study of type material. With type or possible type
   material of 20 nominal species-group taxa of Ampullariidae, belonging to
   the genera Afropomus Pilsbry and Bequaert, 1927 (1 taxon, from Africa),
   Felipponea Dall, 1919 (2, South America), Forbesopomus Bequaert and
   Clench, 1937 (1, Asia), Lanistes Montfort, 1810 (2, Africa), Pila
   Roding, 1798 (2, Asia), and Pomacea Perry, 1810 (11, South, Central, and
   North America), as well as 1 incertae sedis taxon in Pila or Pomacea,
   the U.S. National Museum of Natural History, Smithsonian Institution,
   has significant holdings, for which this annotated catalogue is
   provided. To stabilize the nomenclature, lectotypes are designated for
   eight species-group taxa. No new synonyms are proposed, other than as a
   result of the provision of a replacement name for elongata Dall, 1921,
   non d'Orbigny, 1842, nec Rochebrune and Germain, 1904. Accounts are
   arranged alphabetically by original published species-group name.
   Information in each account includes original name and combination,
   citation to the original description, current taxonomic status, type
   material held by the U.S. National Museum (holotypes, paratypes,
   syntypes, lectotypes, paralectotypes, and one neotype) with catalogue
   number(s) and number of specimens in each catalogue lot, type locality,
   and other remarks or additional information as appropriate. All
   name-bearing types are illustrated.
C1 Hayes, Kenneth A.; Department of Biology, Howard University, 415 College
   St. Nw, Washington, D.C., 20059, USA, USA.
EM kenneth.hayes@howard.edu
SC Education &Educational Research; Zoology
SN 0081-0282

   name; Taxonomy; Animals and man; Education and entertainment;
   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Nearctic region; North America;
   USA
DE Ampullariidae [Museums collections and exhibitions / National Museum of
   Natural History / type material; systematics] [Catalogues / Annotated
   catalogue / ] [District of Columbia / Washington / ]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Prosobranchia, Mesogastropoda,
   Viviparoidea
OR Ampullaria (Felipponea) elongata - Dall 1921 (Viviparoidea): [Lectotype
   designated, P. 4]. 
   Ampullaria (Felipponea) neritiniformis - Dall 1919 (Viviparoidea):
   [Lectotype designated, P. 6]. 
   Ampullaria aurostoma - Lea 1856 (Viviparoidea): [Lectotype designated,
   P. 3]. 
   Ampullaria elongata - Bennett 1831 (Viviparoidea): [Nomen nudum, P. 4]. 
   Ampullaria gracilis - Lea 1856 (Viviparoidea): [Lectotype designated, P.
   5]. 
   Ampullaria pinei - Dall 1898 (Viviparoidea): [Lectotype designated, P.
   7]. 
   Ampullaria turbinis - Lea 1856 (Viviparoidea): [Lectotype designated, P.
   8]. 
   Ampullariidae - Gray 1824 (Viviparoidea). 
   Felipponea dalli (Viviparoidea): [Nom nov, For Felipponea elongata Dall
   1821, p. 4]. 
   Felipponea elongata - Dall 1821 (Viviparoidea): [Preoccupied name
   replaced by, Felipponea dalli, p. 4]. 
   Paludina sinistrosa - Lea 1838 (Viviparoidea): [Lectotype designated, P.
   7]. 
   Pomacea (Effusa) oligista - Pilsbry & Olsson 1953 (Viviparoidea):
   [Taxonomic position, P. 6]. 
   Pomacea zischkai - Blume & Pain 1952 (Viviparoidea): [Type material,
   Exclusions from type series, p. 9].

PT J
AN ZOOR15311070790
DT Article
TI New Data on Albian-Coniacian Radiolarians from the Kelevudag Section
   (Northeastern Azerbaijan).
AU Bragina, L.G. (l.g.bragina@mail.ru) 
   Bragin, N. Yu.
SO Stratigrafiya Geologicheskaya Korrelyatsiya
VL 23
IS 1
PS 45-56
PD Jan 2015
PY 2015
NT Serial normally translated cover to cover in: Stratigraphy and
   Geological Correlation.
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The reinvestigation of upper Albian and Cenomanian radiolarians from the
   Albian-Late Cretaceous Kelevudag section of northeastern Azerbaijan
   described in classical works by Kh.Sh. Aliev revealed the presence of
   upper Turonian-? lower Coniacian species among their assemblages. The
   identified radiolarian taxons form several successive assemblages:
   Dorypyle ? anisa-Crolanium triangulare (upper Albian), Patellula
   spica-Trisyringium echitonicum (Cenomanian), Orbiculiforma
   quadrata-Pseudodictyomitra pseudomacro-cephala (upper Turonian-? lower
   Coniacian). It is established that the species Dictyomitra sagitafera
   Aliev belongs to the genus Pseudodictyomitra.
C1 Bragina, L.G.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Geol, Pyzhevskii Per 7, Moscow,
   119017, Russia, Russia.
EM l.g.bragina@mail.ru
RI Bragin, N. Yu/S-8501-2016; Bragina, Liubov G./C-4197-2019
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 0869-592X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Taxonomy; Taxonomic position;
   Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia; Geological time
   periods; Mesozoic
DE Radiolaria [Fossil assemblages /  / ] [Azerbaijan / North-east,
   Kelevudag section / stratigraphical distribution] [Cretaceous / Albian /
   ] [ / Late Cretaceous / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Actinopoda, Polycystinea
OR Radiolaria (Actinopoda): [Fossil]. 
   Dictyomitra sagitafera - Aliev (Polycystinea): [Referred to,
   Pseudodictyomitra, p. 45]. 
   Pseudodictyomitra sagitafera - (Aliev) (Polycystinea): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Dictyomitra, p. 45].

DT Article
TI A new species of Harpactocarcinus A-Milne-Edwards, 1862 (Crustacea,
   Brachyura, Zanthopsidae) from the Eocene of Lessini veronesi Mounts
   (Northern Italy).
FT Una nuova specie di Harpactocarcinus a. Milne-edwards, 1862 (crustacea,
   Brachyura, Zanthopsidae) dell'eocene dei monti Lessini veronesi (italia
   settentrionale).
AU Beschin, Claudio (beschin.cl@libero.it) 
   De Angeli, Antonio
   Checchi, Andrea
SO Studi e Ricerche Associazione Amici Museo Civico "G. Zannato" Montecchio
   Maggiore (VI)
VL 22
PS 15-23
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA Italian
U1 0
U2 0
AB The genus Harpactocarcinus A. Milne-Edwards, 1862 has had an ample
   diffusion in the European Tethys sea during the Cenozoic. The known
   species for the Venetian territory are attributed to Harpactocarcinus
   punctulatus (Desmarest, 1822); H. fedrigoi Beschin, De Angeli & Zorzin,
   2014; H. macrodactylus A. Milne-Edwards, 1862; H. ovalis A.
   Milne-Edwads, 1862; H. rotundatus A. Milne-Edwads, 1862 and H.
   yozgatensis Schweitzer, Shrk, Cosovia, Okan, Feldmann, Hosgor, 2007. The
   study describes Harpactocarcinus spinosus n. sp. associated to H.
   punctulatus from the Eocene of Forte Masua (Lessini veronesi Mountains,
   northern Italy).
C1 Beschin, Claudio; Collaboratori Museo Civ G Zannato, Piazza Marconi 17,
   Vicenza, I-36075, Italy, Italy.
EM beschin.cl@libero.it
SC Zoology
SN 1127-3100

   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary;
   Palaeogene
DE Harpactocarcinus spinosus [Italy /  / new species] [Eocene /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates

   Decapoda, Reptantia, Brachyura
OR Harpactocarcinus spinosus (Brachyura): [Sp nov, Italy, Eocene, P. 17;
   Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR15401000481
DT Article
TI The Black Fungus Gnats (Diptera: Sciaridae) of Papua New Guinea. Part IV
   Genera Bradysia and Chiasmata gen. nov.
FT Die Trauermuecken (Diptera: Sciaridae) von Papua-Neuguinea. Teil IV
   Gattungen Bradysia und Chiasmata gen. nov.
AU Mohrig, Werner (wmohrig@hotmail.com) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 22
IS 1
PS 3-38
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB As a result of a taxonomic study of the Black Fungus Gnats (Sciaridae)
   of Papua New Guinea the present article deals with 37 species, of which
   36 belong to the genus Bradysia WINNERTZ, 1867 and one is classified in
   a new genus, Chiasmata gen. nov. The new taxa, including 33 species
   ofBradysia, are described and illustrated. Most of the new Bradysia
   belong to either the B. fungicola species group (9 species) or the B.
   hilaris species group (21 species). Three of the new Bradysia cannot be
   assigned to any of the species groups known from the Palaearctic.
   Characters to identify Bradysia spatitergum (HARDY, 1956), B.
   planistylata VILKAMAA, HIPPA & MOHRIG, 2012, and B. gibbosa VILKAMAA,
   HIPPA & MOHRIG, 2012 are discussed. The geographical distribution of B.
   spatitergum is discussed in the light of new collection data from the
   Afrotropical and Oriental Regions.
C1 Mohrig, Werner; Puddemin 6, Poseritz, D-18574, Germany, Germany.
EM wmohrig@hotmail.com
SC Zoology
SN 0945-3954

   Eurasia; Asia; India; Australasia

DT Article
TI Trichoceromyia oregonensis gen. et spec. nov., a third Catotrichinae
   (Diptera: Cecidomyiidae) from the Nearctic Region.
AU Jaschhof, Mathias (mjaschhof@yahoo.de) 
   Fitzgerald, Scott J.
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 22
IS 1
PS 59-66
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB The Catotrichinae are a species-poor group of fungivorous Cecidomyiidae
   (gall midges), whose adult morphology is characterized by mainly
   plesiomorphic traits. As for the extant species, five are placed in the
   Holarctic genus Catotricha EDWARDS, 1938 and two in the Australian genus
   Trichotoca JASCHHOF & JASCHHOF, 2008. A new Nearctic catotrichine
   described here from Oregon, USA, differs so markedly from both
   Catotricha and Trichotoca that it is classified in its own genus and
   named Trichoceromyia oregonensis gen. et spec. nov. It is the first
   catotrichine in which adults (males) have a regressive morphology,
   manifested in the lack of ocelli, presence of short, two-segmented
   palpi, and absence of setae on the wing membrane. Other uniquely derived
   characters relate to the flagellum, the venation, and the abdomen. Male
   genitalic structures in Trichoceromyia are similar to those in
   Trichotoca, but, considering that those structures are not very complex,
   the similarity observed may be due to parallel evolution. New records
   are reported for a Catotricha spec., presumably C. americana (FELT,
   1908) from Quebec, which is the first Canadian record of Catotrichinae,
   and for C. subobsoleta (ALEXANDER, 1924) from Oregon.
C1 Jaschhof, Mathias; Stn Linne, Olands Skogsby 161, Farjestaden, S-38693,
   Sweden, Sweden.
EM mjaschhof@yahoo.de
SC Zoology
SN 0945-3954
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America; Canada; USA
DE Catotricha americana [Quebec /  / New record]. 
   Catotricha subobsoleta [Oregon /  / New record]. 
   Catotrichinae [Nearctic region /  / New record; systematics] [Canada / 
   / ]. 
   Trichoceromyia oregonensis [Oregon /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Diptera, Nematocera, Cecidomyiidae
OR Catotricha americana (Cecidomyiidae): [New record]. 
   Catotricha subobsoleta (Cecidomyiidae): [New record]. 
   Catotrichinae (Cecidomyiidae): [New record]. 
   Trichoceromyia (Cecidomyiidae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Catotrichinae,
   Type species Trichoceromyia oregonensis, p. 61]. 
   Trichoceromyia oregonensis (Cecidomyiidae): [Sp nov, Oregon, P. 63].

TI A contribution to the knowledge of Polytrichophora CRESSON (Diptera:

   new species.

PS 67-76
PD 2015

LA English

AB Three new species of the Ephydrid genus Polytrichophora are described:
   P. graeca spec. nov. (Greece), P. jordanensis spec. nov. (Jordan), and
   P. indistincta spec. nov. (Germany). A key for the five West Palaearctic
   Polytrichophora species is presented and the male postabdomen of all
   species is illustrated.

DT Article
TI Revision of the European Empis (s. str.) simulium-group of species
   (Diptera: Empididae), with descriptions of four new species from the
   European mountains.
AU Chvala, Milan (mchvala@natur.cuni.cz) 
   Pont, Adrian C.
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 22
IS 1
PS 89-110
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The Empis simulium-group of species is clearly defined, and is
   represented by rather medium-sized species of Empis s. str.
   distinguished in the males by the very long, slender, and very
   characteristically distinctly undulating aedeagus. The species are known
   mostly from the Central European mountains. Altogether 14 European
   species are included here, four of which were originally classified in
   Rhamphomyia subgenus Aclonempis COLLIN, 1926 which was very recently
   synonymized with the genus Empis LINNAEUS, 1758. Three new species from
   the Alps Empis brunohubli spec. nov., Empis hubli spec. nov., Empis
   atrosimulium spec. nov. - and one new species from the Romanian
   Carpathians - Empis carpathica spec. nov. - are described here.
C1 Chvala, Milan; Charles Univ, Fac Nat Sci, Vinicna 7, Prague, 12844 2,
   Czech Republic, Czech Republic.
EM mchvala@natur.cuni.cz

   species] [Switzerland /  / ].

   Transferred from Rhamphomyia (Aclonempis), p. 103].

DT Article
TI New records of big-headed flies (Diptera: Pipunculidae) from Portugal.
AU Kehlmaier, Christian (kehlmaier@web.de) 
   Andrade, Rui
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 22
IS 1
PS 137-151
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Faunistic data of 42 species of big-headed flies for mainland Portugal
   are presented, adding 39 species to the national fauna (and 40 species
   to the fauna of mainland Portugal, respectively). A record of
   Clistoabdominalis trochanteratus (BECKER, 1897) is the first in Europe.
   Cephalops lusitanicus spec. nov., a sibling species of Cephalops ultimus
   (BECKER, 1900), is newly described and the female of Chalarus immanis
   KEHLMAIER, 2008 is characterized for the first time. Pipunculus
   subflavus BECKER, 1921 syn. nov., previously regarded synonymous with C.
   perspicuus (DE MEIJERE, 1907), is proposed as a junior synonym of C.
   ultimus (BECKER, 1900). The check-list of Portuguese Pipunculidae now
   comprises 45 named species, of which all are known from mainland
   Portugal, two from Madeira, and none from the Azores.
C1 Kehlmaier, Christian; Senckenberg Nat Hist Collect Dresden, Museum Zool,
   Konigsbrucker Landstr 159, Dresden, D-01109, Germany, Germany.
EM kehlmaier@web.de
SC Zoology
SN 0945-3954

   Documentation; Publications; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe

TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates; True Flies

   Cephalops (Semicephalops) lusitanicus (Pipunculidae): [Sp nov, Portugal,
   P. 141].

   synonymy, Pipunculus subflavus Becker 1921, p. 144]. 
   Cephalops ultimus - (Becker 1900) (Pipunculidae): [Syn nov, Pipunculus
   subflavus Becker 1921, p. 144]. 
   Chalarus immanis - Kehlmaier 2008 (Pipunculidae): [First time described,
   Female, p. 145].

   described on the basis of male and female adults, pupae and fourth
   instar larvae collected from Itupararanga reservoir, Silo Paulo State,
   Brazil. The new species differs from the described Chaoborus species by

TI Cheilotrichia (Empeda) savchenkoi spec. nov., a new species of
   Limoniidae (Diptera) from the Altai Mountains.
AU Devyatkov, Vladimir I. (devyatkovvi@inbox.ru) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 22
IS 2
PS 211-214
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Cheilotrichia (Empeda) savchenkoi spec. nov., a new species of
   short-palped craneflies, is described and illustrated based on male and
   female adults from the Altai Mountains. The new species is clearly
   distinguished from all other species of the subgenus Empeda
   OSTEN-SACKEN, 1869 by the yellow colour of the body. Two further
   species, Cheilotrichia (Empeda) cinerascens (MEIGEN, 1804) and
   Cheilotrichia (Empeda) neglecta (LACKSCHEWITZ, 1927), are reported as
   new to the fauna of Kazakhstan.

DT Article
TI Leafminer flies (Diptera: Agromyzidae) of the fauna of Russia and
   adjacent countries: The genus Agromyza FALLEN.
AU Nartshuk, Emilia Petrovna (chlorops@zin.ru) 
   von Tschirnhaus, Michael
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 22
IS 2
PS 215-232
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB A list of 48 species of the genus Agromyza FALLEN, 1810 (Agromyzidae)
   occurring on the territory of Russia and adjacent countries together
   with localities and collection data is given. The first faunistic
   records from 7 European and 13 Asian countries in the Palaearctic Region
   are presented. All the species were determined by V. V. ZLOBIN
   (1953-2008) and are kept in the collections of the Zoological Institute
   of the Russian Academy of Sciences in St. Petersburg, Russia. A new
   synonym of Agromyza viciae KALTENBACH, 1872 (= Agromyza quadriseta
   ZLOBIN, 2001 syn. nov.) is established, as well a new synonym of A.
   drepanura (MAmoNov, 1929) comb. nov. (= Agromyza drepanura HERING, 1930
   syn. nov.). All synonyms and known host plant genera are given for each
   taxon. A distribution table of the listed species of Agromyza in
   European countries is given, adding 232 first country and realm records
   to the "Fauna Europaea" that were either published but hitherto
   overlooked or are here documented for the first time. Data for the
   European part of Russia are organised following the five regions
   proposed in "Fauna Europaea".
C1 Nartshuk, Emilia Petrovna; Russian Acad Sci, Zool Inst, Univ Skaya Nab
   1, St Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.
EM chlorops@zin.ru
SC Zoology; Parasitology
SN 0945-3954

   distribution; faunal list] [Russia /  / ].

AN ZOOR15411073642
DT Article
TI The horseflies (Diptera: Tabanidae) of Madagascar Part 2: Subfamily
   Chrysopsinae, tribe Rhinomyzini.
AU Zeegers, Theo (th.zeegers@xs4all.nl) 
SO Studia Dipterologica
VL 22
IS 2
PS 259-304
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The tribe Rhinomyzini of the subfamily Chrysopsinae from Madagascar is
   revised. The revision is based on the study of a large amount of
   material recently collected by Malaise traps, most type specimens, and a
   review of the literature. All 26 species of Rhinomyzini occurring on
   Madagascar are endemic; they constitute more than a quarter of all
   Malagasy Tabanidae species. Five species are described as new to
   science: Oldroydiella albocincta spec. nov., Tabanocella bimaculata
   spec. nov., T hauseri spec. nov., T quentini spec. nov., and
   Thriambeutes melanochrysa spec. nov. Orgizocella pauliani QUENTIN, 1990
   syn. nov. is synonymized with Tabanocella seyrigi Stun', 1951. The
   number of genera occurring on Madagascar is reduced from ten to four due
   to the following new synonymizations: Seguytabanus PAULIAN, 1962 syn.
   nov. and Jashinea OLDROYD, 1970 syn. nov. are synonymous with
   Oldroydiella DIAS, 1955. Mackerrasia Dias, 1956 syn. nov.,
   Tabanocellinus DIAS, 1966 syn. nov., Alocella QUENTIN, 1990 syn. nov.,
   and Orgizocella QUENTIN, 1990 syn. nov. are synonymous with Tabanocella
   BIGOT, 1856. The proposed synonymies lead to five new combinations at
   the species level. Rhinomyzini are fairly abundant and species-rich on
   Madagascar, so they form an important part of the horsefly fauna there.
   The eastern rainforest region is a hotspot of rhinomyzine diversity. The
   affinities of the Malagasy Rhinomyzini have been suggested to be with
   those of the African mainland and those of the Oriental region. Based on
   our current knowledge of the timeline of continental drift and horsefly
   evolution, vicariance cannot be excluded as a mechanism to explain the
   occurrence of the tribe in both the Malagasy and Oriental regions.
C1 Zeegers, Theo; Eikenlaan 24, Soest, NL-3768 EV, Netherlands,
   Netherlands.
EM th.zeegers@xs4all.nl
SC Zoology
SN 0945-3954
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; Key; Ecology; Zoogeography; Land zones; Afrotropical
   region; Africa
DE Oldroydiella; Tabanocella [Madagascar /  / Key to species]. 
   Oldroydiella albocincta; Tabanocella bimaculata; Tabanocella hauseri;
   Tabanocella quentini; Thriambeutes melanochrysa [Madagascar /  / New
   species]. 
   Rhinomyzini [Ecology / Biodiversity / systematics; revision]
   [Zoogeography /  / ] [Madagascar /  / Key to genera] [ /  / biology;
   distribution; faunal list].

   Tabanidae

   Orgizomyia - Gruenberg 1906 (Tabanidae): [Status, P. 269]. 
   Rhinomyzini - Enderlein 1922 (Tabanidae): [Diagnosis, P. 261; Key to

   Seguytabanus oldroydi - Paulian 1962 (Tabanidae): [Referred to,
   Oldroydiella, p. 267]. 
   Tabanocella - Bigot 1856 (Tabanidae): [Syn nov, Alocella Quentin 1990,
   p. 275; Syn nov, Mackerrasia Dias 1956, p. 275; Syn nov, Orgizocella
   Quentin 1990, p. 275; Syn nov, Tabanocellinus Dias 1966, p. 275; Key to
   species, Madagascar, P. 297]. 
   Tabanocella bimaculata (Tabanidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 276]. 
   Tabanocella hauseri (Tabanidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 282]. 
   Tabanocella quentini (Tabanidae): [Sp nov, Madagascar, P. 292]. 
   Tabanocella seguy - (Quentin 1990) (Tabanidae): [Comb nov, Transferred
   from Alocella, p. 294].

   pauliani Quentin 1990, p. 294].

DT Article
TI Revalidation of Dolichothele Mello-Leitao and notes on Hapalotremus
   Simon (Araneae, Mygalomorphae, Theraphosidae).
AU Lucas, Sylvia Marlene (sylviamlucas@gmail.com) 
   Indicatti, Rafael Prezzi
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 50
IS 3
PS 204-212
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Hapalotremus exilis (Mello-Leitao, 1923) and Hapalotremus muticus
   (Mello-Leitao, 1923), previously considered as nomina dubia are here
   revalidated through the examination of the holotypes. Dolichothele
   Mello-Leitao, 1923 is revalidated and their type species, Dolichothele
   exilis Mello-Leitao, 1923 is restored. Goniodontium Mello-Leitao, 1923
   and Oligoxystre Vellard, 1924 are considered junior synonyms of
   Dolichothele. Hapalotremus muticus and Oligoxystre caatinga Guadanucci,
   2007 are considered junior synonyms of D. exilis. All species of
   Oligoxystre are transferred to Dolichothele. Cyclothoracoides Strand,
   1929, currently a junior synonym of Hapalotremus Simon, 1903, is here
   considered a junior synonym of Homoeomma Ausserer, 1871.
C1 Lucas, Sylvia Marlene; Inst Butantan, Lab Especial Colecoes Zool, Sao
   Paulo, Brazil, Brazil.
EM sylviamlucas@gmail.com
RI Indicatti, Rafael P/D-5745-2012

SN 0165-0521
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy; Taxonomic
   position

ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae

DT Article
TI Description of Neoholothele gen. nov. (Araneae, Theraphosidae,
   Schismatothelinae).
AU Guadanucci, Jose Paulo Leite (joseguadanucci@gmail.com) 
   Weinmann, Dirk
SO Studies on Neotropical Fauna and Environment
VL 50
IS 3
PS 221-228
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The new genus Neoholothele is herein described based on the results of a
   recent phylogenetic analysis. This phylogeny, which included
   representatives of all Theraphosidae subfamilies, showed that the genus
   Holothele, as hitherto defined, does not comprise a monophyletic group.
   Neoholothele gen. nov. is diagnosed by the following features: males and
   females with dark carapace and golden cephalic region; females with
   striped color pattern on the abdomen dorsum and long and slender
   spermathecae receptacula; males with retrolateral branch of male tibial
   spur with apical end wider than proximal end (synapomorphy), with two
   apical spines. It comprises two species: N. incei (F. O.
   Pickard-Cambridge, 1898) comb. nov. and N. fasciaaurinigra sp. nov.,
   both from northern South America.
C1 Guadanucci, Jose Paulo Leite; Univ Estadual Paulista, Inst Biociencias,
   Rio Claro, Brazil, Brazil.
EM joseguadanucci@gmail.com
RI Guadanucci, Jose Paulo/J-6856-2012
OI Guadanucci, Jose Paulo/0000-0001-9724-9010
SC Zoology
SN 0165-0521
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Type species; Combination;
   Taxonomy; Taxonomic position; Land zones; Neotropical region; South
   America
DE Neoholothele fasciaaurinigra [Colombia /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Araneae
OR Hapalopus incei - F.O. Pickard-Cambridge 1898 (Araneae): [Designated
   type species for new genus, Neoholothele, p. 222]. 
   Holothele incei - (F.O. Pickard-Cambridge 1898) (Araneae): [Referred to,
   New genus Neoholothele, p. 223]. 
   Neoholothele (Araneae): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Schismatothelinae, Type
   species Hapalopus incei F.O. Pickard-Cambridge 1898, p. 222]. 
   Neoholothele fasciaaurinigra (Araneae): [Sp nov, Colombia, P. 225]. 
   Neoholothele incei - (F.O. Pickard-Cambridge 1898) (Araneae): [Comb nov,
   Transferred from Holothele, p. 223]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15312079647

PT J
AN ZOOR15307039024
DT Article
TI Taxonomical study on a sample of land snails from Alcobaca (Bahia,
   Brazil), with description of a new species.
AU Salvador, Rodrigo Brincalepe (salvador.rodrigo.b@gmail.com) 
   Lopes Simone, Luiz Ricardo
SO Stuttgarter Beitraege zur Naturkunde Serie A (Biologie)
VL 8
PS 1-7
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A sample of land snails, mainly pulmonates, was recently (August 2012)
   collected in a fragment of Atlantic rainforest, in the vicinity of the
   city of Alcobaca (south of Bahia state, Brazil); its study is urgent
   both from a taxonomical as well as from an environmental point of view.
   The geographical ranges of Beckianum beckianum (Subulinidae), and
   possibly also of Rectartemon piquetensis (Streptaxidae), are extended to
   Bahia. Specimens of Helicina angulifera (Helicinidae), Gastrocopta
   oblonga (Gastrocoptidae), Bulimulus tenuissimus and Leiostracus vimineus
   (Bulimulidae), and Burringtonia pantagruelina (Odontostomidae), already
   known to Bahia, were also found. Moreover, Solaropsis akobacensis n. sp.
   (Pleurodontidae) is described herein. The finding of this new species is
   a stark reminder of how little the Brazilian terrestrial snail fauna is
   known and of how such forest fragments may serve as refuges for endemic
   species and should therefore be properly preserved.
C1 Salvador, Rodrigo Brincalepe; Staatl Museum Nat Kunde Stuttgart,
   Rosenstein 1, Stuttgart, D-70191, Germany, Germany.
EM salvador.rodrigo.b@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Biodiversity &Conservation; Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 0341-0145
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Conservation; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Beckianum beckianum; Rectartemon piquetensis [Brazil / Bahia / New
   record]. 
   Pulmonata [Conservation /  / Systematics; annotated faunal list] [Brazil
   / Bahia, Alcobaca / distribution]. 
   Solaropsis alcobacensis [Brazil /  / New species]. 
TN Invertebrates; Molluscs
ST Animalia, Mollusca, Gastropoda, Pulmonata, Stylommatophora,
   Achatinoidea, Camaenoidea, Streptaxoidea
OR Pulmonata (Gastropoda). 
   Beckianum beckianum (Achatinoidea): [New record]. 
   Solaropsis alcobacensis (Camaenoidea): [Sp nov, Brazil, P. 5]. 
   Rectartemon piquetensis (Streptaxoidea): [New record]. 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR15307039024
DA 2020-09-17

DT Article
TI Revision of the Oriental species of the genus Caenis Stephens (Insecta:
   Ephemeroptera: Caenidae).
AU Malzacher, Peter (malzacher.lb@t-online.de) 
SO Stuttgarter Beitraege zur Naturkunde Serie A (Biologie)
VL 8
PS 27-47
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB 29 described species of Caenis Stephens, 1835 are known from the
   Oriental Region. In this contribution, eight of these species are
   revised, five of them are declared as 'species inquirenda'. Seven new
   species of Caenis are described herein: Caenis nigropunctatula n. sp.
   (Sumatra, Java, Thailand), C. ranauensis n. sp. (Sumatra), C. ulmeriana
   n. sp. (Sumatra, Java, Thailand), C. maratha n. sp. (India), C. guttata
   n. sp. (Thailand), C. gephyria n. sp. (Thailand), and C. incurva n. sp.
   (India). A key is provided for 14 species that can be differentiated by
   modern diagnostic criteria.

   Germany.

DT Article
TI A revision of the Megalopaederus species of Taiwan (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae: Paederinae).
AU Assing, Volker (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Stuttgarter Beitraege zur Naturkunde Serie A (Biologie)
VL 8
PS 53-94
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Megalopaederus Scheerpeltz, 1957, previously regarded as a distinct
   genus, is assigned to the genus Paederus Fabricius, 1775 as a subgenus.
   The Megalopaederus species of Taiwan are revised. In all, eighteen named
   locally endemic species belonging to two species groups are recognized,
   thirteen of them are described and illustrated for the first time:
   Paederus (Megalopaederus) virgifer n. sp. (Nantou, Chiai); P. (M.)
   incurvatus n. sp. (Kaohsiung); P. (M.) adiectus n. sp. (Pingtung); P.
   (M.) aequilobatus n. sp. (Pingtung); P. (M.) furcispinosus n. sp.
   (Nantou); P. (M.) excisissimus n. sp. (Pingtung); P. (M.) trihamatus n.
   sp. (Taoyuan); P. (M.) bivirgatus n. sp. (Hualien); P. (M.) anmamontis
   n. sp. (Taichung); P. (M.) semiflavus n. sp. (Taitung); P. (M.) alesi n.
   sp. (Hualien); P. (M) discurrens n. sp. (Taichung); P. (M.) incisus n.
   sp. (Nantou). Rescriptions and illustrations of the five previously
   described species, as well as of P. (M.) lewisi Cameron, 1930 from Japan
   and P. biacutus Li et al., 2013 from mainland China are provided, and P.
   (M.) bucculentus n. sp. (Japan: Honshu: Nagano Prefecture) is described.
   The latter three species were included in the revision to tentatively
   assess the phylogenetic affiliations of Taiwanese Megalopaederus.
   Paederus fulvocaudatus Adachi, 1939, previously considered a subspecies
   of P. kosempoensis Bernhauer, 1922, represents a distinct species. A
   lectotype is designated for P. kosempoensis Bernhauer, 1922. Additional
   material composed exclusively of females and probably representing six
   undescribed species is listed. The available information on the natural
   history of Taiwanese Megalopaederus is compiled. A key to the named
   species of Taiwan is provided. Their distributions are mapped.
C1 Assing, Volker; Gabelsbergerstr 2, Hannover, D-30163, Germany, Germany.
EM vassing.hann@t-online.de

DT Article
TI On the Staphylinidae (Coleoptera) of Crete II. Seven new species, a new
   synonymy, and additional records.
AU Assing, Volker (vassing.hann@t-online.de) 
SO Stuttgarter Beitraege zur Naturkunde Serie A (Biologie)
VL 8
PS 95-112
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Approximately 110 species of Staphylinidae collected in 2013 and 2014
   are reported from the Greek island Crete. Seven species of Aleocharinae
   (four species), Paederinae (one species), and Staphylininae (two
   species) are described and illustrated, five of them are probably local
   endemics: Bellatheta albimontis n. sp. (Lefka On), B. idana n. sp.
   (Psiloritis), Geostiba (Sipalotricha) paulexsecta n. sp. (Psiloritis),
   Myrmecopora (Myrmecopora) thriptica n. sp. (Orno Thriptis; associated
   with Messor sp.), Sunius thripticus n. sp. (Orno Thriptis), Quedius
   praecisus n. sp. (Orno Thriptis, but probably more widespread in Crete),
   and Xantholinus erinaceus n. sp. (several localities). The sexual
   characters of some previously described species are illustrated. The
   following synonymy is proposed: Quedius nemoralis Baudi di Selve, 1848 =
   Q. candicus Coiffait, 1976, n. syn. The genus Bellatheta Roubal, 1928 is
   reported from Crete for the first time. Some previous records are
   rectified. The diversity and biogeography of the endemic species of
   Crete is discussed. A revised list of the 67 currently known named
   endemic (sub-) species of Staphylinidae of Crete is provided.
C1 Assing, Volker; Gabelsbergerstr 2, Hannover, D-30163, Germany, Germany.
EM vassing.hann@t-online.de
SC Zoology
SN 0341-0145
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Synonymy; Documentation;
   Publications; Zoogeography; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia;
   Europe; Greece
DE Bellatheta [Crete /  / New record]. 
   Bellatheta albimontis; Bellatheta idana; Geostiba (Sipalotricha)
   paulexsecta; Myrmecopora (Myrmecopora) thriptica; Quedius praecisus;
   Sunius thripticus; Xantholinus erinaceus [Crete /  / New species]. 
   Staphylinidae [Checklists / Revised checklist / ] [Zoogeography /
   Biogeography & endemism / ] [Crete /  / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Beetles; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Coleoptera, Polyphaga, Staphylinoidea,
   Staphylinidae
OR Staphylinidae (Staphylinoidea). 
   Bellatheta (Staphylinidae): [New record]. 
   Bellatheta albimontis (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Crete, P. 103]. 
   Bellatheta idana (Staphylinidae): [Sp nov, Crete, P. 105].

PT J
AN ZOOR15307039031
DT Article
TI Studies on Stiliderus Motschulsky and Stilicoderus Sharp:
   biogeographical notes and descriptions of new species (Coleoptera:
   Staphylinidae: Paederinae).
AU de Rougemont, Guillaume (gderougemont@hotmail.co.uk) 
SO Stuttgarter Beitraege zur Naturkunde Serie A (Biologie)
VL 8
PS 113-130
PD 2015
PY 2015
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The following 22 new species are described and named: Stilicoderus
   aerosoides n. sp., S. baliemensis n. sp., S. batantaensis n. sp., S.
   cephalicus n. sp., S. continentalis n. sp., S. kolaensis n. sp., S.
   lastianus n. sp., S. laticeps n. sp., S. lobatus n. sp., S. maritimoides
   n. sp., S. meraukeanus n. sp., S. obesus n. sp., S. papuanus n. sp., S.
   riedelianus n. sp., S. riedeli n. sp., S. sarahae n. sp., S. sepikensis
   n. sp., Stiliderus agostii n. sp., S. brendellianus n. sp., S. germanus
   n. sp., S. rugulosicollis n. sp. and S. tengah n. sp. Another three
   species (Stilicoderus sp. X, Stiliderus sp. Y and Stiliderus sp. Z) are
   described to enable differentiation from other members of the aerosus
   group, but not named for want of males. Stilicoderus pendleburyi Cameron
   1950 n. syn. is placed in synonymy with Stilicoderus fenestratus Fauvel
   1895. New country records are given for eleven other species. A summary
   of the distribution of species groups, particularly in biogeographical
   sub-regions known for high rates of endemicity, is presented.
